chapter.title: Building ANF Clinical Statements User Guide
chapter.para: This guide aims to provide an approachable introduction to understanding and building Analysis Normal Form (ANF) data structures, also called ANF statements, from existing clinical narratives and clinical terminology data. This guide explains all the components of an ANF statement and how those components are populated using real world clinical narrative examples.
As an introductory document, this guide does not encompass all the statement details and capabilities that ANF offers but provides a solid introduction.

section.title: Why Standardized Clinical Statments?
section.para: Healthcare data standardization is crucial for ensuring data quality, consistency and interoperability across different health care systems and institutions. The amount of available healthcare data is ever increasing and analysis of that data, either for patient care or research purposes, requires that everyone is “speaking the same language.” Lack of timely access to accurate patient data can significantly hinder the provision of appropriate medical care and result in undesirable patient outcomes.

There are many challenges in the current landscape of health data standardization. Patient heath care data is often fragmented, sourced from many different healthcare systems that use their own codes and terminologies. This leads to an incomplete or inaccurate picture of the patient’s medical history, rendering decision support to be unreliable and unsafe. It is difficult to aggregate clinical information managed by health information networks without a common format that provides semantic clarity and high quality.​

Standardized clinical statements provide a structure that allows clinical data to be accurately interpreted and analyzed, regardless of the source. Consider medical data to be akin to financial data. Standardization in finance aims to create uniform processes, data formats and reporting practices to ensure consistency, transparency and efficiency in financial operations and reporting. The Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), ensures that companies are following the same rules when reporting finances, thus maintaining investor trust in the financial market. Just as with financial data, medical data needs to be standardized to ensure quality and reliability of the data. It would be unwise to make an investment in a company whose financial statements didn’t delineate gross from net income. It would be equally unwise to create a treatment plan for a patient based on bloodwork numbers that may be missing information like fasting versus non-fasting.

Medical data is its own language, that requires both terminology and a structure to effectively communicate a patient’s health story. In migrating from historical paper-based medical records, where most of the information was in free-text narratives, to electronic medical records, medical terminologies (i.e., SNOMED, LOINC, etc.) were used to try to bridge the gap by codifying disorders, symptoms and other relevant clinical information. But the coding was often haphazard and led to inconsistencies in the documentation of medical information. Providing a robust Structure for the communication of medical Terminologies allows for the unambiguous exchange of information between systems.

Medical data can communicate much more when structured into an ordered statement. Standardized clinical terminology is essential, but it cannot capture much of the context that is important to clinical care, such as purpose, prerequisites, causality, etc. Incorporating structure through effective order and rules can allow terminology to produce a standardized clinical statement. ANF is an HL7® balloted model for clinical statement representation that is intended to safely and reliably support data analysis and can be used to aggregate data created using any standard or non-standard input form or exchange mechanism.​

section.title: What are ANF Statments?
section.para: As a data structure, ANF is designed to prevent terminology misrepresentations, reduce data variation, increase data integrity, and improve clinical decision support (CDS) to ensure patients receive proper care. The ANF model allows for representation of any type of clinical data in a comprehensive, yet simple form. Data would maintain its meaning and quality through the specific separations of concerns that are needed to capture data the same way every time.ANF is proposing a common format that provides semantic clarity and high-quality data capturing which could easily aggregate clinical information managed by multiple health information networks.

ANF statements are comprised of two basic components, the “Context” and the “Circumstance,” () each having their own unique set of data elements or “attributes” which capture, in a uniform and normalized way, all the clinical detail of the statement. Both the Context and the Circumstance are required to create a normalized clinical statement.

Just like words in language, the context is critical to understanding clinical terminology. For instance, the word “chip” could be a small piece of wood, a thin crispy piece of potato, or a small piece of silicon, and context would help determine which definition is meant (e.g. eating a chip versus installing a chip). The Context has a number of data elements or “attributes” which describe what the ANF statement is about (See Figure 1). Perhaps the most important attribute is the “Topic.” The topic is what the ANF statement is about (the action, observation, request). To further specify the context around the information provided in the clinical statement, the ANF structure also includes data elements that intake basic, objective background information such as who the statement is about, who is authoring the clinical statement and when was the statement created. In addition, the Context component of the ANF statement will identify what type of Circumstance is involved and the purpose of the action.

The Circumstance provides the clinical detail for the ANF Statement. There are three types of Circumstances that can be part of an ANF statement: Performance Circumstance, Request Circumstance and Narrative circumstance (). Each type of circumstance has its own unique set of attributes to capture the unique data germane to the specific circumstance. A Performance Circumstance specifies the result of an action or an observation. The Request Circumstance describes a request made by a clinician for a patient. The Narrative Circumstance is intentionally not meant to be used frequently and is only intended to document components of the clinical narrative that cannot be documented by the data structure of the Performance or Request Circumstances.
ANF Statement Components: Context and Circumstance

section.title: Clinical Element Isolation
section.para: Medical data is often complex, and clinical narratives can contain a lot of different types of information, like demographics, symptomology, test results and imaging data. ANF statements follow the principal of “Clinical Element Isolation,” which simply put, is the organization of medical data or processes into distinct units or components each addressing a singular key element of the clinical narrative (Clinical Element). Each ANF statement contains an individual element of the patient data. For any given clinical narrative, there are a number of Clinical Elements that would need to be identified. When identifying the Clinical Element, it is important to ensure that the Clinical Element represents the most basic, or simplest term. ANF statements are then created for each of the separate Clinical Elements.
The following in an example of a simple clinical narrative:

para.emphasis: A 58-year-old male presents at urgent care with a temperature of 102.5 and a sore throat.

section.para: Analysis of the clinical narrative allows for the separation of clinical information to four basic elements (). The clinical narrative states that the patient is a 58-year-old male which, when separating Clinical Elements, results in two separate ANF statements about the patient’s demographic data, one for the patient’s age (58 yo) and one for the patient’s gender (male). In addition, there is information in the narrative regarding the patient’s symptoms, each of which would be the topic of its own ANF statement (one for Body Temperature, and one for Sore Throat). In this example, there are 4 separate “Clinical Elements” that will be dealt with in 4 separate ANF Statements. Break Down of Clinical Narrative into Clinical Elements for ANF Statements

For the purpose of an ANF statement, each Clinical Element should exist independently. For example, a clinical narrative statement of “negative for COVID-19 and RSV” would result in two separate ANF statements, one with COVID-19 as the Topic and one with RSV as the topic, the result of both being “false” (negative). This holds true for compound observations as well, such as a PERRLA test. PERRLA is an abbreviation that stands for Pupils Equal, Round, and Reactive to Light and Accommodation. A PERRLA test assesses whether the pupils are of equal size, round, constrict when exposed to light, and adjust their size when focusing on near and far objects. To accurately document a normal PERRLA result would require treating the result like a panel and breaking it down into the simplest elements. The result would be 4 separate ANF statements, one for each of the PERRLA observations.

Sometimes the Clinical Element and the resulting ANF Topic are the same. As seen in Figure 2, For the Clinical Element of “sore throat”, the Topic of the ANF statement is also “sore throat”. Typically, if the result is qualitative (yes/no), then the Clinical Element and the Topic will be the same. If the result is quantitative (a numeric measure) then the Clinical Element and the Topic will be different, as the Clinical Element will be a numeric finding in the clinical narrative and the topic will describe what the number is. For example, for the Clinical Element of temperature of 102.5, the Topic would be Body Temperature.

section.title: Associated Statements
section.para: As described above, ANF statements are a type of standardized clinical statement that follow the principle of Clinical Element Isolation. Given this distillation down to the simplest element, a single ANF statement may not provide the breadth needed to describe a clinical data point. Associated Statements are secondary ANF clinical statements that provide additional information that is associated with the primary ANF statement. The Associated ANF statements follow the exact same criteria as outlined above and are full ANF statements.

For example, to capture all the information about a patient’s smoking status, there may be a main ANF statement with regards to smoking status (Smoker, non-smoker, former smoker) and associated statements about the number of cigarettes per day, the years smoked, or the length of time since quitting. Associated statements may contain performance circumstances, request circumstances or narrative circumstances depending on the information that needs to be captured in the statement.

section.title: Data Element Types
section.para: In Analysis Normal Form (ANF), each statement is built from a standard structure which captures the clinical information. This standard structure will contain different data element types, depending on what kind of information is being captured. These data types are summarized in the table below () and are discussed in further detail below.

title.emphasis: Data Types used in ANF statement attributes

row.entry: Numeric value with a standard unit
Provider ID, lab number, patient ID

section.para: A Concept represents a coded term from a controlled vocabulary, such as SNOMED CT, LOINC, or RxNORM. For example, in an ANF statement capturing the results of a systolic blood pressure measurement, the topic would be:
Concept: Systolic blood pressure (observable entity) SCTID: 271649006

However, there are times when an appropriate concept does not exist to accurately describe an item in a clinical narrative or encounter. In this case, a new concept would be created and submitted for approval, while using a system generated public ID would be used in the interim to encode the concept. The SNOMED codes used herein by way of example are accurate as of July 2025 (SNOMED CT BROWSER).

The Measure data type is used to represent a quantitative value which includes both the numeric component and an associated unit of measure. The unit of measure will be defined by the semantic for the numeric component. This data type is typically used to describe results, interventions or other actions that involve numeric quantities. It is important to note that the measure is not used for ordinal values (e.g. “mild” or “moderate) or binary/Boolean values (e.g. yes/no, true/false). The numeric component of the measure can be represented using a primitive type like Decimal, for exact values, or Float, for approximate values although this is used less commonly in healthcare due to rounding issues. The units for a measure data point need to be standardized.

In the case where there are multiple values or measures, such as systolic and diastolic measures for blood pressure, these would typically be modeled as separate ANF statements, one for systolic measure and one for diastolic measure.
Systolic BP
Value: 120
Standardized Unit: mmHg
Diastolic BP
Value: 85
Standardized Unit: mmHg

Another example would be a complete blood count, or a comprehensive metabolic panel where there are multiple numeric results for the different components of the panel. Each result in the panel would have a separate ANF statement with the measurand as the topic and the numeric measure for the result.

A Boolean data type in ANF is used to represent a binary outcome in which the value can only be True or False. It captures the presence or absence of a condition, the result of a yes/no question, or any clinical fact that has only two possible states. For example, if the ANF statement had a topic of Ulcers of the Mouth, the Boolean answer would be “Present” (True) or “Absent” (False). There may be times when the result is unknown and therefore can’t be coded as true or false. In this case, the result would deal with a three-valued logic, such as “True,” “False” or “Unknown” the result would be a Ternary result.

The Integer data type is used to represent whole number values without decimals or units. The data type is typically used for counts or scores, like number of doses taken, or where the patient feels their pain is on a 1- 10 scale.

The String data type is used to capture free-text narrative information that cannot be fully expressed in structured, coded formats. It allows clinicians to document patient-reported symptoms, complex histories, impressions, or contextual details in their own words. This data type is not machine-interpretable in the same was as other structured data types but may be required to preserve the completeness of the medical record.

The Date/Time data element is used to represent specific time points or ranges related to a clinical statement, such as when a test was performed, when a symptom began, or when a medication was administered. ANF statements use the standard time format or Unix Epoch time.

The Identifier data element is used to represent a unique reference to an object or entity. For example, to identify the practitioner that is authoring a clinical statement, the ANF statement may include the provider’s National Provider Identifier (NPI) number as the unique ID. A lab reporting test results may be identified by their Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) number. This allows ANF statements to link structured clinical content to external systems.

section.title: Identifying the Key Elements of a Clinical Narrative
section.para: The first step in creating ANF statements is to break down the clinical narrative into the simplest key parts (or Clinical Elements) of information. The Clinical Elements will convey the key clinical and demographic aspects of the narrative relating to the patient.

All clinical narratives will contain information that may touch on demographics, medical history, current health issues or prescribed testing or regimens. The first step in creating ANF statements to convey the clinical information is to separate and articulate the key Clinical Elements. It is important to remember that any information that is not included in the clinical narrative should not be inferred.

Once all the key Clinical Elements have been identified, the Topic for each ANF statement can be determined and the specific attributes for Context and Circumstance can be populated. In order to illustrate how to break down the clinical narrative, determine the topic and populate the associated attributes, the following clinical narrative will be used as an example ().

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative for a Syphilis Use Case

para.emphasis: Due to a recent case of Syphilis at Shadow Pines nursing home, resident testing was recommended. Roberta is a resident. Patient is a 70-year-old white, Hispanic female. Upon examination, the patient has no evidence of genital lesions, no evidence of white spots in mouth, and no evidence of any rash on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet. The patient reports being sexually active with 2 male partners over the past 12 months. The patient denies a history of Syphilis but reports a lack of regular STI screening in the past. Finger prick blood sample collection was performed to obtain a capillary sample for laboratory testing for Syphilis using the Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR) Test. The sample was labeled and sent to the lab for same day analysis, with results coming back as "non-reactive." Patient was advised to have repeat testing in 3 months. The patient has been counseled on the importance of follow-up testing to ensure accurate diagnosis and timely treatment if needed.

Results of repeat testing using the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test were positive. Disease status noted as early and results and disease state submitted to the state and local public health departments as required. Patient counseled on positive result and referred to Dr. Smith, facility physician for treatment plan.

section.para: The clinical narrative above contains multiple key Clinical Elements that can be identified and separated into separate ANF statements, each with their own Topic and relevant attributes. The first step is to identify the separate pieces of relevant clinical information for the patient as seen in the table below ().

title.emphasis: Isolation of Clinical Elements for Syphilis use case narrative

row.entry: No white spots in the mouth
No rash on the palms of the hands
No rash on the soles of the feet
2 male sexual partners in the past year
Request for 3 month follow up testing
Patient education on syphilis testing importance

section.title: Determining the Topic of an ANF Statement
section.para: Once each of the Clinical Elements have been identified, the next step is to determine what the Topic should be for each of the elements. The Topic is the central component of clinical statements and abides by several principals. Principle 1 is that the Topic defines an action that is being requested, measured or observed. Principle 2 is that the Topic must be able to exist on its own and still retain original intent and clarity of meaning. The 3rd principal is that the Topic can only contain one Clinical Element.

ANF requires an ability to define a precise Topic of a statement using a logical standard terminology expression. For the syphilis use case clinical narrative above, topics can be assigned to the Clinical Elements that were identified. It is important to understand that the Topic chosen requires a clear measure or result of what was observed, requested or assessed during treatment. The Topic should be as specific as possible, so the result “reacts” to the topic. Per the example above about smoking, the topic of the ANF statement would not be “Smoking status,” for an individual patient it would be “Smoker”, and the result would be a qualitative result of “yes.”

The result will fall into one of two categories: a quantitative result or a qualitative result. A quantitative ANF statement would have a result that is intended to represent a numeric result. A qualitative ANF statement would have a result that represents the presence or absence of a topic, essentially is the topic “true” or “false.” The way in which these types of results are represented in the ANF statement will be discussed later.

Take for example the fact that the patient, Roberta, in the syphilis clinical narrative in (), was 70 years old. It is easy to understand that the topic for that Clinical Element would be “Current Chronological Age”, and the result would be “70”. This is an example of a Quantitative Result ANF statement. The clinical narrative also states that the patient is female. It may seem that the logical Topic for this statement would be “Sex at Birth” with a result of “Female.” However, this is an example of a qualitative ANF statement. As the ANF logical model does not allow for the representation of a result as a String, and gender is not a quantitative measure, the result will be “true” and thus the topic will be either “Male”, “Female”, or “Intersex” depending on the individual patient that the statement was about.

title.emphasis: Isolated Clinical Elements and resulting Topics from the Syphilis use case Clinical Narrative. Table shows alignment with existing Clinical Terminology in SNOMED, current as of July 2025.

entry.emphasis: Existing Clinical Terminology Concepts for the Topic

row.entry: Depending on specific patient, the topic concept would be “Female”, “Male “or “Intersex”
Depending on the specific patient, the topic concept would be “American Indian race”, “Asian race”, “African race”, “Pacific Islander race” or “Caucasian race”
Depending on the specific patient, the topic concept would be “Hispanic” or “not Hispanic”
No white spots in the mouth

emphasis.emphasis: This is not quite right so we would need to create a new concept: Concept "oral lesion with white color"

row.entry: No rash on the palms of the hands
No rash on the soles of the feet
Sexually active in last year (finding): SCTID: 714095007
2 male sexual partners in the past year
Number of partners in the past year
Number of sexual partners in past year (observable entity): SCTID: 228463002
Request for 3 month follow up testing
Depending on the specific patient, the Topic concept would be “Primary syphilis”, “Secondary syphilis” “Latent syphilis” or “Late (tertiary) syphilis”

section.para: As seen in the table above, the Topic will often align with an established clinical term or concept that may be present in the SNOMED or LOINC databases. However, there are times when the SNOMED or LOINC terminology isn’t an exact match for what the topic of the ANF statement should be or there may be no code at all to describe the topic. For example, to describe the white spots in the mouth, the Topic is “Oral Lesion with white color.” The closest SNOMED code is “Oral Lesion” (SCTID: 1081000119107), but the color description is missing and that is a key clinical feature of the oral syphilis lesions. In this case, a new concept would need to be created for the Topic for “Oral lesion with white color,” assigned a unique ID and submitted to SNOMED as a new extension. For denoting the patient’s ethnicity, a new concept for “not Hispanic” would need to be created as there is no code for that in SNOMED (as of July 2025).

It is possible to have multiple ANF statements with the same Topic. In the Syphilis use case, there are two ANF statements with the Topic of “Eruption of Skin.” From the clinical narrative you can see that there is assessment of the presence of an “Eruption of Skin” (rash) on the palms of the hands, as well as the soles of the feet. To comply with the isolation of clinical information down to the most basic element, the Topic for both statements is “Eruption of Skin,” and the location of the “Eruption of Skin” is dealt with in the Circumstance attributes.

Equally important as noting presence of a symptom, noting the absence of a symptom in a clinical narrative is crucial because it provides clear evidence that a specific clinical feature was actively assessed and found to be missing, which can directly impact diagnosis, treatment decisions, and clinical interpretation. For example, in the evaluation of syphilis, documenting the absence of a rash (on the soles of feet, or palms of hands) helps differentiate between stages of the disease and may rule out secondary syphilis, where rash is a hallmark symptom. Without explicitly stating its absence, a provider reviewing the record may be uncertain whether the symptom was simply not present or not examined at all. Another example would be notation of the presence or absence of a family history of a disease or condition. For many diseases, including hereditary cancers and cardiovascular conditions, family history plays a key role in risk stratification, screening decisions, and preventive care planning. Without explicitly noting that a patient has no known family history, it may be unclear whether the information was omitted, unavailable, or simply not asked. Clearly stating the absence helps ensure that future providers or specialists can make informed decisions. This level of detail supports clinical reasoning, enhances diagnostic accuracy, and ensures completeness and clarity in the medical record, especially important in complex or ambiguous cases.

section.title: Determining What Type of Circumstance is Appropriate
section.para: For ANF statements, the Circumstance provides the clinical detail of the requested or performed action (the Topic). There are three types of Circumstances that can be part of an ANF statement: Performance Circumstance, Request Circumstance and Narrative circumstance. The ANF statement will contain the correct Circumstance and associated attributes for the Topic along with the timing and purpose (if applicable) for the circumstance (). Different narratives require different circumstances. Allowing clinicians to choose between circumstance instances further categorizes the flow of data, allowing for ease of access later. Figure 4: The Circumstance provides the clinical detail for the ANF statement.

A single ANF statement will only use one type of circumstance, either a Performance or Request Circumstance. In general, Performance Circumstance is used to document an action or an observation that has happened in the past or in the current time of the ANF statement creation, whereas a Request Circumstance will describe action to be taken in the future. The Narrative Circumstance is intentionally not meant to be used frequently and is only intended to document components of the clinical narrative that cannot be documented by the data structure of the Performance or Request Circumstances and require free text entry.

A Performance Circumstance specifies the result of an action. That action can be a medical test or procedure, a statement of fact about the patient, such as age or gender, or the presence or absence of symptoms. All the details about the action or fact are documented in the Performance Circumstance, such as test result, reference range, type of specimen, etc. The Performance Circumstance will be described in more detail in later sections.

The Request Circumstance describes a request made by a clinician for the patient, such as an order for lab work, or instructions for diet and exercise. Oftentimes, the object of the request will be fulfilled by someone who is not the original requesting clinician. All details about the request are documented in the Circumstance attributes, including details of frequency, repletion, expected result, etc. The Request Circumstance will be described in more detail in later sections.

The Narrative Circumstance is intentionally not meant to be used frequently and is only intended to document components of the clinical narrative that cannot be documented by the data structure of the Performance or Request Circumstances. For example, an ANF statement may document the presence of a mutation in the BRCA1 gene. The Narrative Circumstance could contain the exact mutation contained in the BRCA1 gene. The Narrative Circumstance will be described in more detail in later sections.

Going back to the Syphilis use case, a circumstance choice can be determined for each ANF statement Topic (). To demonstrate, the ANF statement Topics in the table are specific to the Patient Roberta in the Syphilis narrative.

title.emphasis: Circumstance Choice for each of the Topics for ANF statements for the Syphilis Use Case (Figure 3)

row.entry: No white spots in the mouth
No rash on the palms of the hands
No rash on the soles of the feet
2 male sexual partners in the past year
Number of partners in the past year
Request for 3 month follow up testing

section.title: Introducing ANF Data Elements (Attributes)
section.para: Once the Clinical Elements and Circumstance Choice have been determined for a clinical narrative, the ANF statements can be built for each of the identified Clinical Elements. ANF statements contain many different data elements, or “attributes” that capture the available health information from a clinical narrative. Both the Context and the Circumstance will have their own set of attributes to capture the unique data germane to the specific circumstance. In order to successfully build out reproducible, standardized ANF statements, one must understand the pieces that fit together to form the ANF statement.

All the attributes for both the Context and Circumstance are cross cutting. A crosscutting attribute is a variable or data element that applies across multiple domains, tables, or entities within a dataset and enables consistent grouping, filtering, or stratification of data for analysis. In other words, a crosscutting attribute is a piece of information that shows up in many different parts of a dataset. For example, the attribute of “location” is a crosscutting attribute, as it will be relevant to a number of ANF statement Topics to describe the anatomical location of the topic.

On the other hand, a clinical attribute that is not crosscutting is one that is specific to a single type of data or observation that doesn’t apply across multiple domains. For example, the attribute of “tumor grade” is specific to pathology reports or oncology staging and doesn’t apply to other domains. Crosscutting attributes are essential for Analysis Normal Form (ANF) because they allow different types of clinical data to be consistently organized, linked, and analyzed across domains.

section.title: Context Attributes (Data Elements)
section.para: As discussed, the Context has a number of data elements or “attributes” which describe what the ANF statement is about. In addition to the Topic, there are a number of other associated attributes for the Context. Each of the potential attributes for the Context of an ANF statement are discussed below. It is important to note that not all attributes are required for every ANF statement. The following simple clinical narrative for Systolic Blood Pressure () will be used to demonstrate the attributes for the Context component of an ANF statement.

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for a Systolic Blood Pressure Use Case

para.emphasis: A 62-year-old man presented to his doctor’s office for a routine checkup. He had a Systolic Blood Pressure of 120 mmHg, taken on his Right Brachial Artery, using BP cuff adult size. Patient in sitting position for at least 5 minutes, urinated not more than 30 minutes prior to measurement.

section.para: The first attribute for the Context portion of the ANF statement is the ID or Identifier. This is the unique ID given to each individual ANF statement. Being able to identify specific ANF statements allows for the ability to associate statements. This is automatically assigned.

The attribute of Time describes when the statement was documented/asserted, like the time that the charting in an electronic health record occurred. Time is expressed as a measure and is recorded in Unix Epoch time. For the Time attribute, there are a number of data points represented in the table below (). These data elements will be described in the context of the date of charting for the example Systolic Blood Pressure clinical narrative (July 9th, 2019).

The lowerBound (float) data element represents the lower bound of the time (or time interval) for documenting a clinical statement. Since we only have the date and not the time of charting, the lowerBound of the Time would be 12:00:01 am on July 9th, 2019. This example date and time would be represented as Unix Epoch time as 1562630401 seconds. The includeLowerBound is a Boolean data element used in the context of defining ranges and it determines whether the lower bound of a range should be included or excluded (True = included, False = excluded). In this example, the lower bound would be included and this the entry would be “true.”

The resolution (decimal-primitive) describes the possible or allowed increments in which the measured “thing” can be counted. Given that the time is expressed in Unix Epoch time in seconds, and the semantic for the time measure is seconds, the resolution would be “1” because the time can be counted in 1 second increments.

The upperBound data element represents the upper bound of the time (or time interval) for documenting a clinical statement. Since the narrative only provides the date and not the time of charting, the upperBound (float) of the Time would be 11:59:59 pm on July 9th, 2019. This example date and time would be represented as Unix Epoch time as 1562716799 seconds. The includeUpperBoundis a Boolean data element used in the context of defining ranges and it determines whether the upper bound of a range should be included or excluded (True = included, False = excluded). In this example, the upper bound would be included and this the entry would be “true.” The semantic associated with this attribute is the unit of the Time measure, which is “Seconds.” Therefore, the Semantic or logical expression for this Time example is “Concept Seconds.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Time Attribute for Context

row.entry: Lower bound of the time measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the time measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
The unit of the Time measure

section.para: The subjectOfRecord attribute will always be the patient, or rather the patient’s clinical record. The data elements in this attribute are Id and the associatedSemantic code. The ID is a unique ID. This will typically be the ID assigned to the patient or the patient chart by the healthcare practitioner or organization creating the clinical ANF statement. The semantic/logical expression for this attribute would be Concept “Patient” as seen in .

title.emphasis: Data elements in the subjectOfRecord Attribute for Context

row.entry: Unique ID to Patient’s clinical record
Description of the subject of record

section.para: The Author attribute refers to the list of practitioners or others (social workers, etc.) that authored the clinical statement. It should be noted that the Author could be the patient if the information is from a patient-filled form. If the author is the clinician, the ID would be their personal identifier ID ().

title.emphasis: Data element in the author Attribute for Context

row.entry: Practitioner ID of ordering or charting physician
Concept of “medical Practitioner” or another concept to describe the author

section.para: The subjectofInformation is a logical expression that describes who the statement is about. The patient’s clinical record may contain statements not only about the patient, but also statements about children, relatives and donors. Thus, possible values for this attribute would include the semantics for “subject of record” (which could be the patient), “family member,” or “donor.” The majority of statements will have a value of “patient” since most statements in a patient’s clinical record will be about the patient .

title.emphasis: Data element in the subjectOfInformation Attribute for Context

section.para: The Topic attribute describes what is being requested or what was performed. The Topic is the central clinical concept of clinical statements. As described in section 2B above, the topic abides by several principals. Principle 1 is that the Topic defines an action that is being requested, measured or observed. Principle 2 is that the Topic must be able to exist on its own and still retain original intent and clarity of meaning. The 3rd principal is that the Topic can only contain 1 concept. The Topic data element is a semantic/logical code (Table 9). For the clinical narrative in , the Topic for one of the ANF statements would be “Systolic Blood Pressure.”

title.emphasis: Data element in the Topic Attribute for Context

section.para: The Type attribute is a logical expression for the type of circumstance. It distinguishes between a “Performance Circumstance,” a “Request Circumstance” or a “Narrative Circumstance.”

Performance Circumstances may be observations, such as the observation of a clinical finding/symptom, or the presence or absence of a disorder, or a family history of a disorder. A Performance Circumstance can also describe a procedure or intervention which has been performed on the patient in the past, such as systolic blood pressure, or an appendectomy. A Performance Circumstance will have either a qualitative or quantitative result. For example, in the clinical narrative for Systolic blood pressure, the ANF statement with the Topic of systolic blood pressure would be a Performance Circumstance () and would have the quantitative result of 120 mmHg. For the ANF statement for the patient’s gender, the Topic would be "male" and the result in the performance circumstance would be the qualitative result of "true."

title.emphasis: Data element in the Type Attribute for Context

row.entry: Which type of circumstance is the ANF statement about

section.para: A Request Circumstance describes a request made by a clinician for the patient, such as an order for lab work, or instructions for diet and exercise. For example, for the patient in the systolic blood pressure clinical narrative (Figure 5), the doctor may put a request in the patient’s chart to return in 1 year for blood pressure recheck.

The Narrative Circumstance is not meant to be used frequently and is only intended to document components of the clinical narrative that cannot be documented by the data structure of the Performance or Request Circumstances.
Once the type of circumstance is determined for an ANF statement, the specific attributes germane to that circumstance can be populated.

section.title: Circumstance Attributes (Data Elements)
section.para: The Circumstance of an ANF statement provides all of the clinical detail for the ANF statement. It is important to note that not all attributes are required for every ANF statement. Only the relevant attributes should be configured. For example, “Method” would not be relevant to a question about a person’s age.

Each Circumstance type has specific attributes germane to that circumstance. But, regardless of the type of Circumstance, each Circumstance will have timing associated with the Circumstance and, in some cases, a Purpose for the ANF statement. To demonstrate the attributes of the Circumstance Choice, the following clinical narrative for Urinary Tract Infection will be used by way of example ().

table.title: Clinical narrative example for a Urinary Tract Infection Use Case

para.emphasis: A 32-year-old female presented with dysuria, urinary frequency and suprapubic discomfort which patient reported had started on July 7. A urinalysis showed positive leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and elevated (High) white blood cells (25 WBC/HPF), consistent with a urinary tract infection. The patient was given a prescription for nitrofurantoin 100 mg and instructed to take it orally twice daily for 5 days. She was advised to complete the full course of antibiotics even if symptoms resolve, and to increase fluid intake. If symptoms persist or worsen, or if she develops fever or flank pain, she was instructed to return for further evaluation and to assess kidney function.

section.para: The Time of the circumstance is a measure that describes when the action was performed or requested. For a Performance Circumstance, the Circumstance timing would capture the time when an action or observation took place in the past. For a Request Circumstance, the Circumstance timing would capture the time when the requested action is to take place in the future.

In the UTI clinical narrative, the patient presented on July 9, 2023, with dysuria which had started on July 7, 2023. For the timing for this Performance Circumstance in this ANF statement with Topic dysuria, the time interval would be July 7, 2023, through July 9, 2023.

The data elements for the circumstance timing are the same as discussed for the ANF statement timing (). In this case, the lowerBound (float) data element represents the lower bound of the time (or time interval) for the dysuria symptom, i.e. when the symptom started. Since we only have the date and not the time of the symptom starting, the lowerBound of the Time would be 12:00:01 am on July 7th, 2023. This example date and time would be represented as Unix Epoch time as 1688688001 seconds. The includeLowerBoundis a Boolean data element used in the context of defining ranges and it determines whether the lower bound of a range should be included or excluded (True = included, False = excluded). In this example, the lower bound would be included and this the entry would be “true.”

The resolution (decimal-primitive) describes the possible or allowed increments in which the measured “thing” can be counted. Given that the time is expressed in Unix Epoch time in seconds, and the semantic for the time measure is seconds, the resolution would be “1” because the time can be counted in 1 second increments.

The upperBound data element represents the upper bound of the time (or time interval) for dysuria. Since the symptom dysuria is still present at the time of the appointment, the upper bound would be the date and time of the appointment, which is July 9th, 2024. Since the narrative only provides the date and not the time of charting, the upperBound (float) of the Time would be 11:59:59 pm on July 9th, 2023. This example date and time would be represented as Unix Epoch time as 1688947199 seconds. The includeUpperBound is a Boolean data element used in the context of defining ranges and it determines whether the upper bound of a range should be included or excluded (True = included, False = excluded). In this example, the upper bound would be included and this the entry would be “true.” The semantic associated with this attribute is the unit of the Time measure, concept “Seconds.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Time Attribute for Performance Circumstance

row.entry: Lower bound of the time measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the time measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
The unit of the Time measure

section.para: In the UTI clinical narrative, the patient is directed to return for further evaluation if she developed fever or flank pain. This would be a Request Circumstance but the timing for when the request will happen is a bit unclear. If the request had been to “return in 7 days for follow up urinalysis,” the timing for the Request Circumstance would be clear, return to the office on July 16th, 2023, for a urinalysis. Given that the request is for a conditional future occurrence, meaning only return when and if flank pain or fever develop, the lower and upper bound for the time would be unknown, and therefore the timing attribute for request Circumstance would be left blank ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Time Attribute for Request Circumstance with conditional future occurrence

row.entry: Lower bound of the time measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the time measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
The unit of the Time measure

section.para: In the case of a Narrative Circumstance, the Circumstance timing would reflect when the narrative was charted or when the result for which a narrative is about was received.

The Purpose attribute describes the reason for a performance or request circumstance. Why is the procedure being done? Why is the request being made? The Purpose of a Topic is typically some type of therapeutic or diagnostic intent. There can be more than one therapeutic intent or diagnostic intent. The Purpose data element is a semantic/logical expression. Not all ANF statements will have a documented purpose. As an example, there is no purpose for a Chronological Age ANF statement.

In the UTI clinical narrative above, the Purpose of the request for the patient to return if fever or flank pain develops is to assess for Kidney Infection. As the purpose attribute requires a semantic as the data element, the concept would be a combination of “has focus” and “kidney infection” ().

title.emphasis: Data element in the Purpose Attribute for Circumstance

row.entry: Purpose for the request or performance

section.title: Performance Circumstance Attributes (Data Elements)
section.para: The Status is a coded value to representing the current status of the intervention or observation, such as “performed,” “active” or “on hold.” For example, in the Urinary Tract Infection narrative, a urinalysis was run, including test results for leukocyte esterase, nitrites and white blood cells. Therefore, the status of ANF statement with Topic of leukocyte esterase would be “performed” ().

title.emphasis: Data element in the Status Attribute for Circumstance for Topic Leukocyte Esterase

row.entry: Current status of the action (performed, on hold, etc.)

section.para: The Result attribute is the result of the action or observation. The Result will fall into one of two categories: a quantitative result or a qualitative result. A quantitative ANF statement would have a Result that is intended to represent a numeric result. A qualitative ANF statement would have a Result that represents the presence or absence of a topic, essentially is the topic “true/yes,” “false/no,” or “unknown.”

Quantitative Results are expressed as a Measure, either as a single number result or a result range. The interval can be open or closed depending on whether the upper and lower bounds are included in the measure interval. In cases where the measurable element does not represent a range, upper and lower bound have the same value. For instance, the clinical narrative for UTI states that a 32-year-old female is the patient. In this case, the number does not represent a range, but the beginning and end points of the interval are the same value, 32, meaning the value of the phenomenon is exactly 32. Therefore, for an ANF statement with the Topic of Chronological age, the result would be the number 32, and the unit of measure would be “years” as seen the in .

The Resolution defines the possible or allowed increments in which the measured “thing” can be counted. For the statement about the patient’s age, the Resolution would be “1” because “years old” can be counted in one-year increments. For the clinical narrative with the systolic blood pressure of 120 mmHg, the resolution of this quantitative result would be “1” because the blood pressure measurement can be counted in 1 mmHg increments. If the patient had a fever of 102.5, the resolution would be 0.1, as the temperature can be counted in 1/10th of a degree increments.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Result Attribute for Circumstance demonstrating the result for chronological age per the Urinary Tract Infection Clinical Narrative

row.entry: Lower bound of the result measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the result measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
Semantic for the unit of measure

section.para: Qualitative Results can be Boolean, where there are only two values, “true/yes” or “false/no” or they can be Ternary with a result of “true/yes,” “false/no,” or “unknown. The expressions of the results are [0,0] for "no", [1,INF) for "yes,” and [0,INF) for "unknown." For example, the clinical narrative for UTI states that the 32-year patient is female. For an ANF statement with the topic “Female,” the result would be [1, INF) for “true” as seen the in . This is a Boolean result where there are only two possible values. These two possible results represent a binary distinction and therefore, the Resolution would be “1.” However, for a qualitative result dealing with a three-valued logic, such as “True,” “False” or “Unknown,” the result would be a Ternary result with a resolution of “3.” Regardless of whether the result is Boolean or ternary, the semantic could be “Countable Quantity.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Result Attribute for Circumstance demonstrating the result for female per the Urinary Tract Infection Clinical Narrative

row.entry: Lower bound of the result measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the result measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
Semantic for the unit of measure

section.para: A countable quantity is a type of data element that represents how many of something occurred, is present, or is needed. In a logical model (like the ANF model), it’s used to define values that are discrete, whole-number counts.

The Health Risk Attribute is used to flag a result with coded values to describe the health risk associated with the result of an ANF statement, such as “low,” “normal,” “high,” “critically low,” or “critically high.” This data element is optional. For example, in the clinical narrative for Complete Blood Count, the patient value for Hemoglobin (HGB) was 7.7 g/dl, which is out of the reference range of 11.8 g/dl – 16.8 g/dl. This result is low and therefore is flagged as “Low” in the ANF statement () .

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for a Complete Blood Count Use Case

para.emphasis: A CBC is performed on a 57-year-old Female who presented with fatigue and dark urine. For this patient, the results were:
61.7 % Band Forms and Segmented Neutrophils. (reference range 40.0 - 75.0)

The clinician receives the result of the CBC and is concerned by the patient’s moderate anemia and the finding of degmacytes (bite cells) on the peripheral smear and orders tests for haptoglobin, Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT), Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Enzyme Activity and hemoglobin electrophoresis.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Health Risk Attribute for Circumstance for the Hemoglobin result in the CBC clinical narrative

row.entry: clinical risk of the result (flags results with cited value - low, normal, high, critical)

section.para: The Reference Range is the interval of normal values for the observation/finding described by the Topic. For the Complete Blood Count Use Case (Figure 7) the reference range for Hemoglobin (HGB) is 11.8 g/dl – 16.8 g/dl. Therefore, the lowerBound of the reference range for the ANF statement with topic Hemoglobin would be 11.8 and the upperBound would be 16.8 (). The range is inclusive of the upperBound and lowerBound number and therefore the response to including these numbers is “True.” The Resolution for the Reference Range would be “0.1” g/dl because “g/dl” can be counted in increments of one tenth. The Semantic for the Attribute would be Concept “g/dl.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Reference Range Attribute for Circumstance for the Hemoglobin result in the CBC clinical narrative

row.entry: Lower bound of the range measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the range measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
Semantic for the unit of measure

section.para: The Participant is an optional Attribute that identifies the practitioner(s) responsible for the result. If there is more than one practitioner or individual responsible for the result, each would be listed separately. For example, in the clinical narrative in Figure 5, Dr. Hannah Smith (ID#47-3659) is responsible for the result for systolic Blood Pressure ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Participant Attribute for Circumstance for the Hemoglobin result in the CBC clinical narrative

row.entry: Practitioners or individuals responsible for the result.

section.para: It is possible for the Participant to be the patient, such as a patient self-reporting a body temperature of 101.7.

The Device ID is an Attribute to capture the Unique Device Identifier or the Primary DI for the medical device that was used to get the result for the ANF statement, and the data element is a list of string. Both the test and the instrument (if applicable) are individual medical devices with their own unique device identifiers. For example, in the clinical narrative for the complete blood count. The collected whole blood was run on a Sysmex XN series XN-10 analyzer, and for the WBC result, the reagents used were the Lysercell WNR and Fluorocell WNR reagents, both made by Sysmex. For the ANF statement, the Unique Device Identifiers (UDI) would be listed (). For the Sysmex XN series XN-10 analyzer, the primary DI, per GUDID, is 04987562424214. The device identifier for the reagents is 04987562422982.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Device ID Attribute for Circumstance for the WBC result in the CBC clinical narrative

row.entry: Unique device identifier for medical device used to obtain the result in the ANF statement

section.para: The Method Attribute captures the method applied, either on its own, or in conjunction with the Device, if present, to obtain the result in the ANF statement. As seen in , the Method used to obtain the WBC result in Figure 7 is “Flow Cytometry.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Method Attribute for Circumstance for the WBC result in the CBC clinical narrative

row.entry: Method used to obtain the result (in conjunction with device if applicable)

section.para: The method could also describe the temporary state the patient was actively placed in during the performance of the action. For example, in order to perform a lumbar puncture, the patient must be lying on their side in the fetal position or sitting and leaning forward. The patient would return to normal posture following the collection. Other examples include being instructed to hold their breath during a CT or MRI scan, or patient fasting before an abdominal ultrasound or lipid panel.

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for a patient with Invasive Breast Cancer

para.emphasis: Jane is a 38-year-old female. She previously presented with a palpable mass in her left breast which was biopsied (April 29, 2024). Diagnosis was Invasive Ductal Carcinoma not otherwise specified, Nottingham Grade 3, without Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS). Biomarker analysis by Immunohistochemistry indicated that the tumor was ER/PR/Her2neu negative with a proliferation index as measured by Ki-67 of 75%. Tumor measures 1.5 cm by ultrasound (cT1c), axillary nodes negative. Follow up appointment to discuss Dx. Suggested course of treatment is lumpectomy.

section.para: The Location attribute refers to the anatomical body location of the Topic of the ANF statement. For the clinical narrative in , the patient had a palpable mass in her left breast. The Location attribute allows for the designation of laterality. The ANF statement for the Topic Palpable mass would have a location of “left breast” (). Had there been more detailed location information, such as the palpable mass in the upper portion of left breast, an additional semantic for “upper” could be added to the location.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Location Attribute for Circumstance for the palpable mass result in the invasive breast cancer clinical narrative

row.entry: The body location for the Topic of the ANF statement

section.para: The Specimen Type Attribute includes information for the Substance being sampled or tested, such as whole blood, clean catch urine sample, etc. For the invasive breast cancer narrative, a breast biopsy is performed. For the ANF statement with the topic of “breast biopsy,” the Specimen Type would be breast tissue or breast biopsy specimen ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Specimen Type Attribute for Circumstance for the Breast Biopsy Topic in the invasive breast cancer clinical narrative

row.entry: The substance being sampled or tested

entry.para: Specimen from breast obtained by biopsy (specimen): SCTID: 122601001

section.para: The Specimen Source Site Attribute details the body location from where the specimen was obtained. For the invasive breast cancer narrative, a breast biopsy is performed. For the ANF statement with the topic of “breast biopsy,” the Specimen Source Site would be “Left Breast” ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Specimen Source Site Attribute for Circumstance for the Breast Biopsy Topic in the invasive breast cancer clinical narrative

row.entry: The body location from where the specimen was obtained

section.title: Request Circumstance Attributes (Data Elements)
section.para: The Conditional Trigger Attribute is used to represent a condition, or a set of conditions that must exist in order for request to be executed. For example, in the clinical narrative in Figure 6, The patient is directed to return for further evaluation if symptoms persist or worsen, or fever or flank pain develop. In this case, the ANF statement would have 4 conditional triggers (), any one of which could trigger the request.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Conditional Trigger Attribute for Request Circumstance for the UTI clinical narrative with instructions to return for further evaluation

section.para: Another example would a trigger to take medication. For example, the request could be to take an Ibuprofen 400 mg tablet oral every 6 hours “as needed” for back pain. The use of the Ibuprofen is conditional on the presence of back pain, so the logical expression for the ANF statement for conditional Trigger with the Topic of Ibuprofen 400 mg tablet would be concept “Back Pain.” In the clinical narrative below for a request for some routine bloodwork (), the conditional trigger would be fasting for 8 hours prior to collection.

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for a patient requiring routine bloodwork

para.emphasis: Patient presented for routine follow-up. In light of ongoing fatigue and recent dietary changes, a comprehensive metabolic panel and a complete blood count was ordered. Patient was advised to have blood drawn at Quest Diagnostics to ensure consistency with prior testing. Lab requisition form provided during the visit. Patient instructed to complete the bloodwork within the next 48 hours and to fast for 8 hours prior to collection.

section.para: The Requested Participant Attribute is an optional list of either specific persons or roles who perform and action, assist in performing an action or are targets of the action. In the request for routine bloodwork, the provider makes the specific request that the blood be drawn at Quest Diagnostic. Therefore, the requested participant is a specific Quest Diagnostics lab and the ANF statement would contain the unique identifier (CLIA identifier number) for the designated lab (). If a specific laboratory had not been identified, the Requested participant may have just listed the role of “laboratory” in the ANF statement. Additional “roles” that could be involved as a Requested Participant could be a “specialist” if the request was a referral, a “physical therapist, or nutritionist. It could be the patient themselves if the request was for an action to be taken solely by the patient, like daily blood pressure readings.

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Requested Participant Attribute for Request Circumstance for the Comprehensive Metabolic Panel clinical narrative

row.entry: Identifier of a specific person if requested
Role involved in fulfilling the Request

section.para: The Priority Attribute is a data element which specifies the priority with which a requested action has to be carried out. Requests for medical action will typically be either “Routine,” no urgency to the request, or “STAT,” which requires immediate action. There can be ASAP, urgent but not emergency, or it could be scheduled for a specific timeframe, pre-op/pre-procedure or pre follow up. All requests are considered “routine” unless otherwise specified. For the clinical example in Figure 9, the patient is told to get the bloodwork within the next 48 hours, which would be a routine request ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Priority Attribute for Request Circumstance for the Comprehensive Metabolic Panel clinical narrative

section.para: The Requested Result Attribute contains data elements that specifies the desired, measurable result of the request. In the clinical narrative in , the patient is advised to take two 200 mg tablets of Ibuprofen every 6 hours as needed for pain and inflammation. For the ANF statement with topic “200 mg oral Ibuprofen tablet,” the requestedResult would be [2,2], with 2 for the upper bound and 2 for the lower bound (). The range is inclusive of the upperBound and lowerBound number and therefore the response to including these numbers is “True.” The Resolution for the Reference Range would be “1” tablet because Tablets can be counted in increments of one. The semantic would be “200 mg ibuprofen oral tablet.” The request that it should be taken every 6 hours is taken if in the repetition attribute below.

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for a patient with ankle sprain

para.emphasis: Patient presented to urgent care with left ankle swelling and pain following a skateboard accident. Denies head trauma or loss of consciousness. Physical exam reveals mild edema and tenderness over the lateral malleolus, with intact neurovascular status and preserved range of motion, though limited by pain. No open wounds or deformities noted. An X-ray of the left ankle was obtained and read as negative for fracture or dislocation. Soft tissue swelling present. Diagnosis: ankle sprain.

Patient advised to rest, ice, compress, and elevate the ankle (RICE protocol). Ibuprofen 400 mg (2 200 mg oral tablets) every 6 hours as needed for pain and inflammation was recommended. Patient instructed to limit weight-bearing as tolerated and to follow up with primary care or orthopedic clinic if symptoms persist beyond 7–10 days or worsen.

section.para: If a requestedResult is specified, the appropriate upperBound and lowerBound is specified with the correct result semantic. If a requestedResult is unspecified, the value is set to [0, INF) with a result semantic of "Countable Quantity.”

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Requested Result for Request Circumstance for taking ibuprofen for the Sprained Ankle clinical narrative

row.entry: Lower bound of the range measure
Dictates if the lower bound should be included
Upper bound of the range measure
Dictates if the upper bound should be included
Semantic for the unit of measure

entry.para: Concept “Product containing precisely ibuprofen 200 milligram/1 each conventional release oral tablet (clinical drug)

section.para: The Repetition attribute is an optional data element describes when an action is requested for more than a single occurrence using a measure data structure. It describes how often and for how long an action should be repeated.
There are 5 measures that are represented in the Repetition attribute as described below:

listitem.para: The periodStart field is required for the Repetition attribute and provides the measure for when the repeated action should start. In the Sprained Ankle example in Figure 10, the period start would be “now” as the patient would want to start taking ibuprofen now to help with the pain and swelling. “Now” should be represented using the current timestamp at the time of the documentation or intended action. Using the actual date/time value corresponding to “now” for the narrative in figure 10 would result in a timestamp of 1742242500 in Unix time, and the semantic would be concept “seconds.” If it is not specified in the clinical narrative, the default value of [0,INF) will be used.

The periodDuration field is required for the Repetition attribute and provides the measure for how long the repeated action should persist. For the sprained ankle clinical narrative (Figure 10) the instructions are to follow up with primary care is symptoms don’t resolve in 7 -10 days. Therefore, the period duration would be 7-10 days. If it is not specified in the clinical narrative, the default value of [0,INF) will be used.

The eventSeparation field is required for the Repetition attribute and provides the measure for how long it should be between actions. In the case of taking Ibuprofen, the directions are to take every 6 hours as needed for pain and inflammation. So the eventSeparation would be 6. The “as needed” component of this request would be taken care of in the conditionalTrigger attribute with Concept “pain” and Concept “inflammation.” If it is not specified in the clinical narrative, the default value of [0,INF) will be used.

The eventDuration field is optional for the Repetition attribute and provides a measure for how long each action should last. An example would be icing the ankle for the sprained ankle narrative (Figure 10) and the duration would be to ice for 15-20 minutes every 3 hours for a period of 24 hours (per the RICE protocol). If it is not specified in the clinical narrative, the default value of [0,INF) will be used.

The eventFrequency field is required for the Repetition attribute and provides the measure for how often the action should occur. In the case of taking Ibuprofen, the directions are to take every 6 hours as needed for pain and inflammation. If it is not specified in the clinical narrative, the default value of [0,INF) will be used.

section.para: In terms of the ANF statement, the recommendation of taking Ibuprofen would be as illustrated in .

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Repetition Attribute for Request Circumstance for taking ibuprofen for the Sprained Ankle clinical narrative

row.entry: Represents when a repeated action should begin
Semantic for the unit of measure
Represents how long a repeated action should persist
Semantic for the unit of measure
Semantic for the unit of measure
Represents how long a repetition should persist
Semantic for the unit of measure
Represents how often the action should occur
Semantic for the unit of measure

section.para: The Device ID Attribute for a Request Circumstance is the same as for the Performance Circumstance. The Device ID captures the Unique Device Identifier or the Primary DI for the medical device that is to be used to get the result for the requested action.

For the ANF statement, the data element is a list of string, one string for each of the devices used to carry out the action of the ANF statement. The Medical device can include a test or assay materials and/or an instrument the test is run on, if applicable. This is an optional attribute as a specific device or instrument is not often part of a request. For example, a practitioner may write a request ordering a flu test for a patient but may not specify a particular manufacturer or specific test device.

As in the Performance Circumstance, the Method Attribute captures the requested method to be applied for the requested action. This is an optional Attribute for the request circumstance as a specific method may not be specified in the request. An example of a requested method could be a request for a molecular diagnostic for Flu. The practitioner may not specify a specific manufacturer or specific test, but they may request a PCR-based Molecular Test ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Method Attribute for Request Circumstance for a molecular influenza test

row.entry: Method used to obtain the result (in conjunction with device if applicable)

entry.para: Concept” Detection of Influenza A virus using polymerase chain reaction technique” (procedure)

section.para: The Location Attribute for the Request Circumstance is the same as for the Performance Circumstance. the Location Attribute refers to the anatomical body location of the Topic of the request for the ANF statement. It is possible that there are multiple allowable body locations for a request. For example, a request for a Blood pressure measurement may allow for a body location of either left or right brachial artery. In this case, there would be two concepts for the location as seen in .

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Location Attribute for Request Circumstance for Blood Pressure

row.entry: The body location for the Topic of the ANF statement

section.para: The Specimen Type Attribute for the Request Circumstance is the same as for the Performance Circumstance and includes information for the Substance that will be sampled or tested, such as whole blood, clean catch urine sample, etc. For example, a physician may request that a nasopharyngeal swab specimen be collected to run a SARS-CoV-2 PCR test but due to a septal deviation, the physician may specify that the sample be taken from the right nostril ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Specimen Type Attribute for Request Circumstance for a SARS-CoV test using a nasopharyngeal swab and swabbing the right nostril

row.entry: The substance being sampled or tested

section.para: The Specimen Source Site Attribute for the Request Circumstance is the same as for the Performance Circumstance and details the body location from where the specimen will be obtained. For the example of taking a nasopharyngeal swab from the right nostril, the ANF statement is illustrated below ().

title.emphasis: Data elements in the Specimen Source Site Attribute for Request Circumstance for a SARS-CoV test using a nasopharyngeal swab and swabbing the right nostril

row.entry: The substance being sampled or tested

section.title: Narrative Circumstance
section.para: While Analysis Normal Form (ANF) is designed to normalize and structure much of the clinical content in a patient's chart, there are still several types of information that do not fit neatly into its structured logic and must be preserved as narrative text (string). Examples of this may include the following:

listitem.para: Contextual Detail Not Tied to a Codeable Act: Some clinical detail may be important but doesn’t necessarily fit into a standard code. For example, ANF statements may capture that a patient has a high fever, severe headaches and nausea but it doesn’t capture the fact that the patient had recently traveled to a region with high incidence of Dengue Fever. This information could be captured in an associated narrative statement.

Patient-Reported Descriptions: Vague or subjective patient descriptions are common in clinical encounters, and although they may be vague, the descriptions may be critical for understanding symptoms or guiding differential diagnosis. For example, a patient may describe feeling like “something is crawling under their skin,” or they describe a headache as “different then their usual headaches.”

Historical Narratives or Complex Timelines:These narratives may contain clinically relevant detail which may be difficult to fully represent in the ANF structured model without losing nuance. For example, a patient may report episodes of palpitations that began shortly after taking on caregiving responsibilities for her mother. This may be important in a differential diagnosis to rule out cardiac issues.

section.title: Using Attributes to Build ANF Statements
ANF Statements for Blood Pressure Clinical Narrative
section.para: In order to provide a complete picture of the ANF statements that would result from a clinical narrative, the following section will illustrate how to build all of the required ANF statements for several clinical narratives.
The first clinical narrative describes a systolic and diastolic blood pressure measurement for a 62-year-old man during a routine clinical encounter ().

title.emphasis: Clinical narrative example for blood pressure results

para.emphasis: A 62-year-old man presented to his doctor’s office for routine checkup. He had a Systolic Blood Pressure of 120 mmHg, and a Diastolic Blood Pressure of 85 mmHg, taken on Right Brachial Artery, using BP cuff adult size. Patient in sitting position for at least 5 minutes, urinated not more than 30 minutes prior to measurement. The patient was asked to take his blood Pressure weekly at home for 4 weeks using home blood pressure cuff.

section.para: The ANF statements is presented in the form of a table for each Clinical Element in the clinical narrative in Figure 1. Each ANF statement has two columns, one for “Template” (Yellow Column) and one for “Statement” (Blue Column). The Template column includes a description of the information that will be coded in the ANF statement. The Statement column contains the actual codes. The reason for the two columns is to ensure there is the ability for these statements to be human-readable in the context of this user guide. If a particular attribute is not relevant to the Topic, the cell will be shaded gray.

The first step is to identify the Key Clinical Elements from which the ANF statements will be created (). There will be 7 ANF statements created for this clinical narrative () () () () () () () () () () () () () () . The final two statements regarding sitting and urination will be associated statements linked to the two Blood Pressure measurements, as they clinically do not stand alone in the context of this narrative. These two clinical elements are only important in the context of the blood pressure measurements. The first 6 Clinical Elements include Performance Circumstances in the ANF statement. The final Clinical Element of the blood pressure request includes a Request Circumstance.

title.emphasis: Isolation of Clinical Elements for Blood Pressure Use Case

section.para: For each ANF statement, SNOMED codes are used when available and accurate for the attribute. When an appropriate SNOMED code is not available, a generate Public ID is used. SNOMED codes used are accurate as of July 31, 2025.

section.title: ANF Statements for Medication History
section.para:
The second clinical narrative describes a medication history for a patient with hypertension and prediabetes (). The first step is to identify the Key Clinical Elements from which the ANF statements will be created (). There will be 10 ANF statements created for this clinical narrative: , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,
.

title.emphasis: Medication History Clinical Narrative

para.emphasis: Patient is a 58-year old female with a history of hypertension and pre-diabetes. She is currently taking lisinopril, 20 mg oral tablet, once daily for blood pressure control, which she has been on for the past 2 years with good adherence and tolerability. Prior to starting lisinopril, she was briefly trialed on hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg oral tablet, once daily, but experienced mild dizziness and was switched due to side effects. The patient takes metformin 500 mg oral tablet, twice daily for glucose control which she has been on for the past 6 months.

section.title: List of Attributes Used in ANF Statements
section.para: The following table contains a list of all the attributes used in this user guide to build ANF statements.

table.title: List of Attributes Used in ANF Statements

row.entry: This is the unique ID given to each individual ANF statement.
This attribute describes when the statement was documented/asserted
This attribute will always be the patient, or rather the patient’s clinical record.
This attribute refers to the list of practitioners or others (social workers, etc.) that authored the clinical statement.
This attribute is a logical expression that describes who the statement is about.
This attribute describes what is being requested or what was performed
This attribute is a logical expression for the type of circumstance
The Timing of the circumstance is a measure that describes when the action was performed or requested.
This attribute describes the reason for a performance or request circumstance.
This attribute is a coded value to representing the current status of the intervention or observation, such as “performed,” “active” or “on hold.”
This attribute is the result of the action or observation
This Attribute is used to flag a result with coded values to describe the health risk associated with the result of an ANF statement
This attribute is the interval of normal values for the observation/finding described by the Topic.
This is an optional attribute that identifies the practitioner(s) responsible for the result.
This attribute captures the Unique Device Identifier or the Primary DI for the medical device that was used to get the result for the ANF statement.
This attribute captures the method applied, either on its own, or in conjunction with the Device, if present, to obtain the result in the ANF statement.
This attribute refers to the anatomical body location of the Topic of the ANF statement.
This attribute includes information for the Substance being sampled or tested, such as whole blood, clean catch urine sample, etc.
This attribute details the body location from where the specimen was obtained.
This attribute is used to represent a condition, or a set of conditions that must exist in order for request to be executed.
This attribute is an optional list of either specific persons or roles who perform and action, assist in performing an action or are targets of the action.
This attribute is a data element which specifies the priority with which a requested action has to be carried out.
This attribute contains data elements that specifies the desired, measurable result of the request.
This attribute is an optional data element describes when an action is requested for more than a single occurrence using a measure data structure.
This attribute captures the Unique Device Identifier or the Primary DI for the medical device that was used to get the result for the ANF statement.
This attribute captures the method applied, either on its own, or in conjunction with the Device, if present, to obtain the result in the ANF statement.
This attribute refers to the anatomical body location of the Topic of the ANF statement.
This attribute includes information for the Substance being sampled or tested, such as whole blood, clean catch urine sample, etc.
This attribute details the body location from where the specimen was obtained.
Free Text to document components of the clinical narrative that cannot be documented by the data structure of the Performance or Request Circumstances
